page.title: 12ANDERTON BOAT LIFT,CHESHIRE.
page.content: In 1875, a boat lift was constructed to enable narrow boats to transfer from the Trent and Mersey Canal at Anderton, down to the River Weaver 50 feet below. Boats reached the Lift via a short aqueduct, floating into one of two metal caissons each capable of taking two 70 foot narrow boats. Originally, the Lift operated hydraulically, one caisson going up to the canal as the other descended to the river. In 1908, electric motors wee installed and each caisson enabled to work independently. Anderton Lift is an excellent example of Victorian engineering and ironwork and is considered to be unique. It was recently closed and the Waterways caused an outcry by suggesting it should not be reopened. A campaign for restoration has begun but, at the time of writing, the issue is unresolved.
